The safe region appears in the central portion of the surgical field, showing a diagonal band of dissected tissue where the gallbladder wall is being separated. This area demonstrates the appropriate plane of dissection with yellowish-white fatty tissue and clear anatomical planes. The safe zone extends from the upper middle portion downward and slightly to the left, where the surgical instruments are currently working. This region represents the correct plane for gallbladder dissection, showing adequate exposure and separation from critical structures.

The unsafe region encompasses two main areas: the lower right quadrant and the deeper tissues visible in the bottom portion of the image. These areas appear more vascular and contain darker tissue suggesting proximity to important hepatobiliary structures. The unsafe zone likely contains critical structures such as the cystic duct, cystic artery, and potentially the common bile duct. This region shows more complex anatomical relationships and deeper tissue planes that require careful identification before any dissection can proceed.

The boundary between safe and unsafe regions is marked by a transition from the clearer, more superficial dissection plane to the deeper, more vascular tissues. The surgical instruments visible in the image are appropriately positioned within the safe zone, demonstrating proper technique in maintaining the correct plane of dissection while avoiding critical structures.

Safe List: [37, 38, 39, 52, 53, 54, 55, 67, 68, 69, 70, 71, 83, 84, 85, 86, 99, 100, 101]

Unsafe List: [72, 73, 74, 75, 87, 88, 89, 90, 91, 103, 104, 105, 106, 107, 108, 119, 120, 121, 122, 123, 124, 134, 135, 136, 137, 138, 139, 140]
